"Yasha Levine", "document": null, "cached_page": {"_": "Page", "url": "https://thebaffler.com/salvos/the-crypto-keepers-levine", "blocks": [{"_": "PageBlockCover", "cover": {"_": "PageBlockPhoto", "photo_id": 5840068157555977040, "caption": {"_": "PageCaption", "text": {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "\u00a9 George Bates"}, "url": "https://thebaffler.com/salvos/the-crypto-keepers-levine#", "webpage_id": 4423716840342981408}, "credit": {"_": "TextEmpty"}}, "url": null, "webpage_id": null}}, {"_": "PageBlockTitle", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The Crypto- Keepers"}}, {"_": "PageBlockSubtitle", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "How the politics-by-app hustle conquered all"}}, {"_": "PageBlockAuthorDate", "author": {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Yasha Levine"}, "url": "https://thebaffler.com/authors/yasha-levine", "webpage_id": 0}, "published_date": "2017-09-04 20:00:00.000000"}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "It\u2019s 7:30 p.m. on a Monday in June at an undisclosed location somewhere in northern Europe. I\u2019m sitting in a private dining room in an upscale hotel, talking to Pavel Durov\u2014the \u201cMark Zuckerberg of Russia,\u201d a young internet mogul who had built the country\u2019s most popular social network and lost it to the Kremlin all before he turned thirty. Not long after the famed American whistleblower Edward Snowden had fled to Russia to avoid federal prosecution, Durov had offered Snowden a job\u2014but then himself had to flee Russia because of a widening conflict with the Russian government. Initially hailed as a cyber-dissident because of his spat with the Kremlin, Durov has since drawn the repeated, aggressive interest of American intelligence officials, as well."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "A group of wealthy tourists milled around in the lobby, excitedly chattering about their day of sightseeing and museum tours. Our conversation was of a darker nature. Durov and I were talking about the murky, hyper-paranoid world of the crypto-obsessed privacy movement\u2014a place where spies ruled, nothing was what it seemed, and no one could be trusted."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "For me, the paranoia made sense. For the last three years I had been investigating the grassroots crypto tech accessories at the heart of today\u2019s powerful privacy movement: internet anonymizers, encrypted chat apps, untraceable drop boxes for whistleblowers, and super-secure operating systems that even the NSA supposedly couldn\u2019t crack. These tools were promoted by Pulitzer Prize-winning journalists, hackers, whistleblowers, and the biggest and most credible names in the privacy trade\u2014from Edward Snowden to the Electronic Frontier Foundation and the American Civil Liberties Union. Apps like Tor and Signal promised to protect users from America\u2019s all-seeing surveillance apparatus. And the cryptographers and programmers who built these people\u2019s crypto weapons? Well, many of them claimed to live on the edge: subversive crypto-anarchists fighting The Man, pursued and assailed by shadowy U.S. government forces. Citing harassment, some of them had fled the United States altogether, forced to live in self-imposed exile in Berlin."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "At least that\u2019s how they saw themselves. My reporting revealed a different reality. As I found out by digging through financial records and FOIA requests, many of these self-styled online radicals were actually military contractors, drawing salaries with benefits from the very same U.S. national security state they claimed to be fighting. Their spunky crypto-tech also turned out, on closer inspection, to be a jury-rigged and porous Potemkin Village version of secure digital communications. What\u2019s more, the relevant software here was itself financed by the U.S. government: millions of dollars a year flowing to crypto radicals from the Pentagon, the State Department, and organizations spun off from the CIA."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "My investigation of this community had brought me a lot of abuse: smears and death threats lobbed by military contractors against me and my colleagues; false slanderous stories planted in the press about me being a sexist bully and a CIA agent paid to undermine trust in encryption. So I learned long ago to approach my sources with skepticism and wariness\u2014especially someone as infamous as Durov, who had recently gotten into the crypto business with Telegram, which now enjoys the distinction of being ISIS\u2019s favorite chat app."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Mogul on the Move"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov, who asked me to obscure the location of our meeting because of his ongoing conflict with the Russian government, was wary, too. He had a right to be."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Now thirty-two, he is a multimillionaire\u2014and, if the papers are to be believed, Russia\u2019s most radical internet mogul. In 2006, while only twenty-two, he had cofounded VKontakte (\u201cIn Contact\u201d), a Facebook social networking clone that became more popular in Russia and across the former Soviet Union than Facebook itself. The company didn\u2019t stay under his control for long. In 2011, following mass opposition protests against Vladimir Putin\u2019s ruling party organized largely via social media, the government wanted a firmer grasp over VKontakte. Durov resisted, and pulled off all sorts of acts of defiance: he took photos of documents ordering the company to block certain political groups and posted them online, and publicly mocked officials of Russia\u2019s FSB state security forces."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "But the Kremlin persisted, and finally got its way. Durov had wearied of the Russian state\u2019s steady barrage of dramatic pressure tactics\u2014including attempts by police to raid Durov\u2019s apartment, a bizarre blackmail incident involving what Durov says was a fake video purporting to show him in a black Mercedes running over a traffic cop, and trumped-up criminal charges that forced him to flee the country. So in 2014, the young social media mogul was forced to sell his 20 percent stake of VKontakte to a business concern run by Uzbek-born Alisher Usmanov, a scary billionaire loyal to President Putin. Stripped of his empire, Durov could no longer claim to be the Zuckerberg of the Russian polis."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov fled Russia and, after making a strategic "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "investment"}, "url": "https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/vkontakte-founder-pavel-durov-becomes-citizen-of-st-kitts-and-nevis-34733", "webpage_id": 2222569101100327086}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " on the two-\nisland nation of St. Kitts and Nevis, became a citizen of the Caribbean. For the past three years, he\u2019s lived the life of an autonomous, self-facilitating multimillionaire, wandering the globe living in luxurious hotels, while forsaking material possessions like land and real estate. Durov could have done anything he wanted, and so while in exile, he worked with his elder brother Nikolai on the next big thing: channeling his time and wealth\u2014estimated to be about $300 million\u2014into the development of a new messaging app, Telegram."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "With about 100 million users worldwide, Telegram is ten times smaller than Facebook\u2019s WhatsApp, its closest competitor. But Telegram has found success in strange places: it\u2019s huge in Iran and big in Uzbekistan. It\u2019s got some users in Europe, as well as a growing fan base among Russia\u2019s journalists. It\u2019s also been a big hit with Al-Qaeda and ISIS, who seem to see Telegram as the most secure tool on the market. The groups have used the app\u2019s encrypted chats to plan attacks, while deploying its \u201cpublic channels\u201d feature to broadcast propaganda, recruit lone-wolf terrorists and claim responsibility for successful strikes. Telegram has been implicated in attacks in France, Germany, Turkey and, most recently, in Durov\u2019s hometown of St. Petersburg, where a lone suicide bomber struck a metro station in the heart the city, killing fifteen people and maiming many more."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Getting the Message"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Not surprisingly, the Russian government has again put Durov in its sights. Russian security officials have been pressuring him to share data with them, or risk having his service blocked. But the Russians aren\u2019t the only ones trying to put the screws on Durov. Apparently, the Americans want a piece of the action, too."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "As a waitress brought out a plate of bread and some appetizers\u2014sliced squid and tuna tartar\u2014Durov explained that over the past several years, the FBI has been attempting to pressure him into secretly cooperating with the agency, and that agents had gone as far as trying to bribe one of his developers into becoming a mole. He had never fully discussed the details of his run-ins with the FBI in public\u2014until now."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov says the pressure started in 2014, shortly after he sold his stake in VKontakte. That\u2019s when he first started routinely getting interviewed and questioned by FBI agents on the American border. Sometimes they would detain him for further questioning on entry; other times they would catch up with him to \u201cchat\u201d while he was at the gate getting ready to board a plane. At first, the FBI was curious about his work portfolio at VKontakte and the company\u2019s relationship with Russian law enforcement, including the procedures it followed for complying with government data requests. \u201cI wasn\u2019t comfortable with these questions,\u201d he said. \u201cI had no inclination of becoming an American mole, so I just provided them with the minimum information that was already available in the media.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockBlockquote", "text": {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov and I were talking about the murky, hyper-paranoid world of the crypto-obsessed privacy movement."}}, "caption": {"_": "TextEmpty"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "On later trips, though, FBI officials began asking about Telegram. Where was it based? How did it work? How could the FBI get in touch with Durov in the future? The agents followed up with friendly notes by email, telling Durov to reach out to them if he had trouble or needed help with anything. Durov says he continued to ignore the overtures, but the FBI clearly wanted something; the question was what. In 2016, Durov got his answer. That May, he flew from Europe to San Francisco to attend the annual Google I/O conference. The first morning of his visit, two FBI agents showed up unannounced at eight in the morning at a Mountain View home he was renting through Airbnb. \u201cHow did they get the address?\u201d Durov asks. \u201cMaybe they tracked my sim card? Followed me from the airport? Maybe they got the info from Uber? I don\u2019t know.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "In any event, the two agents were clearly on a mission. \u201cRight away they started asking about Telegram, which made me worry,\u201d says Durov, explaining that it didn\u2019t take long for his early-morning visitors to get to the point: the FBI wanted to set up some kind of informal backchannel process that would enable Telegram to hand over data on particular users in the event of a terrorist threat; they even came prepared with official-looking documents in hand. \u201cThey showed me a court order and told me, \u2018We respect your values about privacy and cryptography very much, and we respect what you\u2019re trying to do. But there is terrorism, it is a serious problem and we have a duty to protect society. We hope you understand and share our views. We want to create a process of data exchange so that you can help us when there is a terrorist threat,\u2019\u201d Durov recounted. During the twenty-minute interview, the agents made it clear they hoped that this was just the start of a long and fruitful relationship."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Telegram is registered in the UK as Telegram Messenger LLP, a company owned by two other companies\u2014one in the British Virgin Islands; the other in Belize. Its data is also cut up and spread out over multiple jurisdictions\u2014part of Durov\u2019s master plan that in theory made legal access to user data as difficult as possible. The company had no legal presence in the United States, and so the FBI had no real authority to demand anything from Durov or his company. Durov said he understood that the court order was a ruse\u2014an attempt to get him to cooperate\u2014but he played along and promised that he would get back to the agents after he had Telegram\u2019s legal team look at the document."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Still, Durov says he was a bit shaken by the experience. \u201cIn Russia, the FSB guys I\u2019ve interacted with were not impressive. They were of middling ability; not really qualified. In the United States, the FBI is different. The ones who questioned me were competent. They spoke multiple languages. They had done their research, and knew exactly what questions to ask. They were of a high caliber. And I understood that America has so many resources dedicated to security that it is downright scary. Law enforcement in America is so much more efficient.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Whack-a-Mole"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The FBI agents went away, but they weren\u2019t done. As Durov tells it, they also had set their sights on a Telegram developer who had flown in for the Google conference, and was also staying at the same Mountain View Airbnb with Durov. (An FBI spokesman declined to discuss any details of Durov\u2019s account with "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The Baffler"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": ".)"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "This developer had already been stopped and questioned at the airport by agents from the FBI\u2019s cyber division, but the FBI scheduled a follow-up meeting at a San Francisco caf\u00e9. The agents who met the developer there started by peppering him with general questions about Telegram\u2019s architecture and how its encryption algorithm worked, all while lavishing him with praise for his expert knowledge. It didn\u2019t take them long to get to what they really wanted: access, for which they were willing to pay. Durov would not disclose the name of this developer, but he recounted the story that his employee eventually told him. The FBI wanted to work out an arrangement in which the developer would secretly feed its operatives information about Telegram\u2019s inner workings\u2014things like new features and other components of the service\u2019s architecture that they might want to know about. The arrangement would be strictly confidential, and they were willing to pay. \u201cWe will make it worth your while,\u201d they said. They said he would be \u201cconsulting\u201d for the FBI\u2014a thinly veiled euphemism for what was clearly a pay-off. \u201cThe FBI agents gave him a range,\u201d said Durov, munching on a piece of bread. \u201cIt was on the order of tens of thousands of dollars.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "After the developer turned down the offer, the FBI met him one more time. This time, the FBI interviewers asked that he not say a word to anyone about their conversation\u2014and especially not to tell his boss. \u201cThey were specific,\u201d said Durov. \u201cDon\u2019t tell Pavel about this, this is our secret.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "He shrugged and smiled. It appeared that the FBI was unable to close the deal. \u201cWe pay our developers very well,\u201d he said in a small flourish of managerial self-congratulation. \u201cOur developers are all millionaires. Naturally they can\u2019t be bribed with that kind of offer.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The FBI trying to turn his own employee into a mole against him? I was expecting Durov to make a big deal out of this disclosure. Silicon Valley companies and crypto privacy types jump at any opportunity to paint themselves as victims of government oppression, and frequently blow up tiny incidents that might redound to their brand advantage in the secrecy wars. Think, for example, of how Apple turned the FBI\u2019s request to unlock a single phone used in a 2015 terrorist attack in San Bernardino that left fourteen people dead into a stand against government oppression\u2014even as the company was also "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "submitting to China\u2019s"}, "url": "https://web.archive.org/web/20160226231729/http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-apple-china-20160226-story.html", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " data demands. (In the end, of course, the FBI got the data it was seeking in the San Bernardino case by using a third-party data hack.) Or there was the recent case of a developer who had worked for Tor, an internet anonymity tool funded by the Pentagon, and fled to Germany after an FBI agent left his business card at her parents\u2019 home."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Given Durov\u2019s libertarian leanings and his proximity to that world, I thought he would start raving against government tyranny\u2014but Durov was surprisingly, almost unnervingly, levelheaded and reasonable about the whole thing. He was troubled and upset by the FBI\u2019s pressure tactics, and pledged to resist all attempts by the agency to get at Telegram\u2019s data. But he wasn\u2019t surprised that it happened, either. After all, that\u2019s what the FBI was there to do. \u201cBasically, the Americans are doing their job. Look at it from their perspective. Here\u2019s a young guy, his app is used by terrorists. We need to find out who he is. What kind of team he has. This is logical. I don\u2019t see anything extraordinary in this,\u201d he said. \u201cI could have gone public with this when it happened and made a big stink. \u2018Look at me, look how the Americans are putting the screws on me.\u2019 But I thought it would be a bit pretentious and melodramatic.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "So why make the story public now? Durov says that he\u2019s coming forward to make a bigger point that\u2019s typically lost in the self-dramatizing scripting of Silicon Valley showdowns with the Feds: what happened to Telegram is quite representative of how the government seeks to gain influence over big data services. \u201cI\u2019m raising this issue only to point out that American security agencies are persistent and pushy, and that they\u2019re just carrying out their jobs. They\u2019ll catch up with you at the airport. They show up unannounced at your Airbnb\u2014the address of which no one should know but you. They try to pay off developers. One way or another, the FBI is very carefully doing its job, and they do all this in the span of just a couple of days that my team and I spend in America,\u201d he says."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "If the FBI was so persistent and pushy with Telegram\u2014going as far as trying to bribe its employees while they are on a short business trip\u2014then what does the U.S. government do to companies permanently based in America? \u201cI can\u2019t imagine myself or anyone else running a privacy-oriented app in that environment. They may start their information requests with data related to terrorism and then gradually widen it to who knows what.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Encrypt or Die!"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "In June 2013, Edward Snowden engineered a data leak heard round the world. An NSA contractor working for the Beltway data and law colossus Booz Allen Hamilton, Snowden blew the whistle on America\u2019s internet surveillance apparatus, and helped shine a light on the symbiotic relationship between Silicon Valley and the U.S. government."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Documents that he stole from an NSA facility in Hawaii provided the first real evidence that our most respected tech companies\u2014including Google, Facebook, and Apple\u2014worked closely with American spies, secretly tapping their own server farms for the NSA and FBI. Snowden\u2019s dramatic leak put the issue of privacy on the internet on the map in a way that it had never been before."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Suddenly, internet privacy was netting daily cable news coverage, "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Frontline"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " investigations, and Pulitzer prizes. There were anti-surveillance protests, online campaigns, and a flurry of reports by government watchdogs and consumer rights nonprofits. Back in 2013, it seemed like we could be on the verge of a global movement that would galvanize people to push for meaningful privacy laws that would not only curb government surveillance, but put limits on Silicon Valley\u2019s unrestricted data collection practices, as well. But things went a different way."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Now, four years after the Snowden leak, we can see that all that energy and outrage and potential for civic action has been redirected into a narrow band of mass-politics-by-app. The new consensus, bruited loudly in and around Silicon Valley, holds that all we need to do to protect ourselves from surveillance is download whatever crypto chat app is in vogue at the moment, and run it on our iPhones. Instead of finding political and democratic solutions to the government and corporate surveillance crisis plaguing our society, the privacy movement somehow ended up in a libertarian rut. In remarkably short order, online privacy advocates had abandoned the idea that people and politics could change the world for the better, and instead chased something closer to an NRA fantasy: the idea that if everyone was equipped with a crypto weapon powerful enough, they could single-handedly take on both corporations and powerful spy agencies like the NSA. They could use technology to guarantee their own privacy on their own terms."}}, {"_": "PageBlockBlockquote", "text": {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "If your enemy was the United States government, it didn\u2019t really matter what crypto app you used."}}, "caption": {"_": "TextEmpty"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Edward Snowden himself has been the principal promoter of this idea, never missing an opportunity to tell people that collective politics is useless, and that arming yourself with technology is where it\u2019s at. He shrugged off the for-profit surveillance that powered the businesses of Silicon Valley, pithily telling the "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Washington Post"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " that \u201cTwitter doesn\u2019t put warheads on foreheads.\u201d Instead, he saw private companies like Apple and Facebook as allies\u2014perhaps the only places that offered even a modicum of safety in the dangerous wilderness of the internet. To him, private developers and software engineers were the true protectors of the people, and he called on them to rise up against government oppression. \u201cIf you want to build a better future, you\u2019re going to have to do it yourself. Politics will take us only so far and if history is any guide, they are the least reliable means of achieving the effective change . . . at the end of the day, law is simply letters on a page. They\u2019re not gonna jump up and protect your rights,\u201d he told the audience at "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Fusion"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "\u2019s "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2016 Real Future Fair"}, "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BUCCCEKrU8o", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " in Oakland via video-robot link from Moscow. To Snowden\u2014now a leaker-\nturned-political-philosopher\u2014political movements and collective action were fickle, merely human endeavors that offered no guarantees; encryption and computer technology was a sure thing, based on the laws of math and physics. \u201cTechnology works differently than law,\u201d the fugitive leaker told the crowd at the Real Future Fair. \u201cTechnology knows no jurisdiction.\u201d"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "It was an absurd position. Substitute \u201ctechnology\u201d with \u201cassault rifle\u201d and Snowden\u2019s speech turns into something you\u2019d hear at a Republican CPAC conference. Still, Snowden got a standing ovation at the Real Future Fair. And why not? From the moment Snowden appeared on the scene, his tech-centric worldview has been backed up by a chorus of award-winning journalists, privacy activists, left-leaning think-tankers, and powerful advocacy groups like the Electronic Freedom Foundation and the ACLU. Silicon Valley supported Snowden\u2019s call to arms, as well. A brave new cohort of app developers backed very narrow technological privacy solutions that they claimed would protect their users from government snooping, all while shamelessly tracking these very same users for private profit and gain."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "As it happened, Snowden\u2019s call to encryption-arms helped inspire Pavel Durov to build Telegram. \u201cI am far from politics and cannot lobby for a ban on total surveillance,\u201d he wrote in "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "October 2013"}, "url": "https://republic.ru/future/programmnyy_tekst_durova-999613.xhtml", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": ", a few months after Snowden fled to Moscow and right before Durov in turn had to flee Russia. \u201cBut there is something that we as IT-entrepreneurs and programmers can do. We can develop and finance technologies aimed at making total surveillance technically impossible.\u201d"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "In America, the initial movement to take the anti-surveillance fight to Silicon Valley fizzled and turned into something else that was at once bizarre and pathetic: privacy activists working with Google and Facebook to fight the NSA with privacy technology. This made precisely as much sense as siding with Blackwater (or Xe or Acadami or whatever the Pentagon contractor calls itself now) against the U.S. Army. Yet this trend of politics-by-app went into overdrive after Donald Trump was elected president. You saw it everywhere: civil libertarians, privacy advocates, and demoralized liberals arose to proclaim that encryption\u2014even the stuff rolled out by Silicon Valley surveillance giants\u2014was the only thing that could protect us from a totalitarian Trump administration."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "\u201cTrump Is President. Now Encrypt Your Email,\u201d urged "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "New York"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " magazine\u2019s technology editor Max Read in an opinion piece published in the "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "New York Times"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " in March. \u201cIn the weeks after Donald J. Trump won the election, a schism threatened to break my group of friends in two. Not a political argument brought about by the president-elect, or a philosophical fight over the future of the country, but a question of which app we should be using to chat. . . .\u201d "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Buzzfeed"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " concurred: \u201cHere\u2019s How To Protect Your Privacy In Trump\u2019s America: Easy tips to shield yourself from expanded government surveillance,\u201d wrote the outlet, offering its millennial readers a listicle guide to \u201cgoing dark\u201d on the net."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "What were these apps? Who made them? Did they really work? That\u2019s where the story got even stranger."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Secrets and Lies"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov\u2019s involuntary encounters with the FBI drive home one unpleasant fact of life in the big data economy: today\u2019s app-obsessed privacy movement relies almost entirely on crypto tools that were hatched and funded by America\u2019s foreign policy apparatus\u2014a body of agencies and organizations that came out of an old-school Cold War propaganda project run by the CIA."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "In 1948, the CIA was "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "given a blank check"}, "url": "https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1945-50Intel/d292", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " to wage a full-spectrum \u201ccovert operations\u201d program to contain and roll back the spread of communism, starting with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Radio propaganda was a central tool in this covert war of ideas, and the CIA used private front groups to run stations with names like \u201cRadio Liberation from Bolshevism\u201d and \u201cRadio Free Europe.\u201d In the 1950s and 1960s, the agency expanded its radio network to include operations targeting communist, left-leaning, and otherwise suspiciously reformist forces that might be spreading the dread bacillus of Bolshevism through Asia and Latin America."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The idea was to prevent these states from exercising sovereign control over their information space\u2014as well as to dominate and influence people\u2019s ideas in a way that aligned with America\u2019s interests. As far as the CIA was concerned, this sub rosa propaganda operation was a beauty, and the agency still proudly boasts that it remains one of the most successful "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "covert psychological warfare"}, "url": "https://www.cia.gov/news-information/featured-story-archive/2007-featured-story-archive/a-look-back.html", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " projects ever run by the United States."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Eventually, the CIA\u2019s multi-tentacled propaganda operation shed its covert status, and was transformed by Congress into the Broadcasting Board of Governors, a sister federal agency to the State Department. With a nearly billion-dollar budget, today the BBG operates America\u2019s sprawling foreign propaganda nexus. The American public is only dimly aware of the BBG\u2019s existence, but this media empire leaves almost no corner of the world untouched by satellite, television and radio transmissions. And just as was the case nearly seventy years ago under the CIA, the mission of the BBG is to systematically perpetrate the very same thing that America\u2019s esteemed political establishment is currently accusing Russia of doing: sponsoring news\u2014some of it objective, some wildly distorted\u2014as part of a broader campaign to project geopolitical power."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "But there was more. When the internet spread around the world, it became a powerful medium of influence, and the U.S. government moved ruthlessly to exploit its competitive edge against rivals under the banner of \u201cInternet Freedom.\u201d The policy, put into place by Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, was about more than just broadcasting news. Its aim was to weaponize this global communications technology in all sorts of creative ways to weaken rivals, topple unfriendly governments, and support opposition movements from China to Russia and Iran, Syria, and Libya. \u201cThe Obama administration is leading a global effort to deploy \u2018shadow\u2019 internet and mobile phone systems that dissidents can use to undermine repressive governments that seek to silence them by censoring or shutting down telecommunications networks,\u201d reported the "}, {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "New York Times"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " in 2011, when the Internet Freedom program first got going in a major way."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockBlockquote", "text": {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The effort includes secretive projects to create independent cellphone networks inside foreign countries, as well as one operation out of a spy novel in a fifth-floor shop on L Street in Washington, where a group of young entrepreneurs who look as if they could be in a garage band are fitting deceptively innocent-looking hardware into a prototype \u2018Internet in a suitcase.\u2019 . . . The suitcase could be secreted across a border and quickly set up to allow wireless communication over a wide area with a link to the global Internet."}}, "caption": {"_": "TextEmpty"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "This was just the beginning. Over the next several years, the BBG, backed by the State Department, expanded the Internet Freedom initiative into a "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "$50 million"}, "url": "https://www.opentech.fund/article/internet-freedom-mandate-congress", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " a year program funding hundreds of projects targeting countries across the world\u2014China, Cuba, Vietnam, and Russia. And here things, yet again, took a turn for the surreal: the Internet Freedom apparatus was designed to project power abroad\u2014yet it also emerged as the primary mover and shaker in America\u2019s domestic privacy movement. It funded activists and privacy researchers, worked with the EFF and ACLU and even companies like Google. Wherever you looked, privacy tools funded by this agency dominated the scene. That included the most ardently promoted privacy products now on offer: Tor, the anonymous internet browsing platform that powers what\u2019s known as the \u201cdark web,\u201d and Signal, the chat app championed by Edward Snowden. Both of them took in millions in government cash to stay afloat."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "From a Whisper to a Scream"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "When Pavel Durov first had VKontakte taken away from him by the Kremlin and fled Russia, he was hailed in the West as a hero\u2014a modern-day Sakharov who fought for freedom and paid the price with his business. America\u2019s crypto and privacy community embraced him, too. But it did not take long for the relationship to sour\u2014and the chief culprit was Signal, a crypto mobile phone app built by a small opaque company called Open Whisper Systems, aka Quiet Riddle Ventures LLC."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Invented by a self-styled radical cryptographer who goes by the name of Moxie Marlinspike (although his real name may or may not be Matthew Rosenfeld or Mike Benham), Signal was brought to life with funding from the BBG-supported "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Open Technology Fund"}, "url": "https://www.opentech.fund/project/open-whisper-systems", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " (which has pumped in almost $3 million since 2013), and appears to rely on continued government funding for survival. Despite the service\u2019s close ties to an organization spun off from the CIA, the leading lights of America\u2019s privacy and crypto community back the app. \u201cI use Signal every day. #notesforFBI,\u201d Snowden tweeted out to legions of followers who went out and downloaded the app en masse. Marlinspike leveraged Snowden\u2019s praise to the max, featuring the leaker\u2019s endorsement prominently on his company\u2019s website: \u201cUse anything by Open Whisper Systems.\u201d"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Largely thanks to Snowden\u2019s endorsement and support, Signal has become the go-to encrypted chat app among American journalists, political organizers, and activists\u2014from anarchists to Marxists to Black Lives Matter. These days, it\u2019s also the secure planning app of first resort for opposition rallies targeting Trump. The app\u2019s even made major inroads into Silicon Valley, with Marlinspike working with management at Facebook and Google to get them to adopt the chat app\u2019s encryption architecture into their mobile chat programs, including WhatsApp. Not surprisingly, Facebook\u2019s adoption of Signal into its WhatsApp program won plaudits from the BBG; managers at the propaganda shop boasted that government-funded privacy tools were now going to be used by a billion people."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Despite Open Whisper\u2019s continued ties to the U.S. government, leading lights of America\u2019s privacy and crypto community have taken to warning off people from using anything else. That includes Telegram, which deploys a custom-built cryptographic technique designed by Pavel Durov\u2019s brother, Nikolai, a mathematician. Even Snowden has taken it upon himself to shoo people away from Telegram, advising political activists, journalists, dissidents, whistleblowers\u2014in short, everyone\u2014to use Signal or even Facebook\u2019s WhatsApp instead. \u201cBy default, it is less safe than @WhatsApp, which makes [it] dangerous for non-experts,\u201d he "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "tweeted"}, "url": "https://twitter.com/Snowden/status/778597417797226496", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " in response to a question from a Telegram-curious supporter."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "But for an app designed to hide people from the prying eyes of the U.S. government, Signal\u2019s architecture has given some security and crypto experts pause. Its encryption algorithm is supposed to be flawless, but the app\u2019s backend runs as a cloud service on Amazon, which is itself a major "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "CIA contractor"}, "url": "https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2014/07/the-details-about-the-cias-deal-with-amazon/374632/", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": ". The program also requires that users connect the app to a real mobile phone number and give access to their entire address book\u2014strange behavior for an app that is supposed to hide people\u2019s identities. Signal also depends on Google and Apple to deliver and install the app on people\u2019s phone, and both of those companies are surveillance partners of the NSA. \u201cGoogle usually has root access to the phone, there\u2019s the issue of integrity. Google is still cooperating with the NSA and other intelligence agencies,\u201d "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "wrote"}, "url": "https://sandervenema.ch/2016/11/why-i-wont-recommend-signal-anymore/", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " Sander Venema, a developer who trains journalists on security. \u201cI\u2019m pretty sure that Google could serve a specially modified update or version of Signal to specific targets for surveillance, and they would be none the wiser that they installed malware on their phones.\u201d And given Signal\u2019s narrow marketing to political activists and journalists, the app works like a flag: it might encrypt messages, but it also tags users as people with something to hide\u2014a big fat sign that says: \u201cWATCH ME, PLEASE.\u201d"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "And anyway, Signal or no Signal, if your enemy was the United States government, it didn\u2019t really matter what crypto app you used. A recent dump of CIA hacking-tool documents published by WikiLeaks revealed that the agency\u2019s Mobile Devices Branch has developed all sorts of goodies to grab phone data, even when it\u2019s quarantined by the firewalls of apps like Signal and WhatsApp or even Telegram. \u201cThese techniques permit the CIA to bypass the encryption of WhatsApp, Signal, Telegram, Wiebo, Confide, and Cloackman by hacking the \u2018smart\u2019 phones that they run on and collecting audio and message traffic before encryption is applied,\u201d wrote WikiLeaks."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov admitted that cryptography has its limits. Still, as he recounted how Snowden had talked down Telegram, Durov was frustrated and bewildered. He says he and his brother were very cautious about choosing cryptography techniques promoted by American experts\u2014particularly since the NSA docs leaked by Snowden revealed the NSA "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "secretly paid"}, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-security-rsa-idUSBRE9BJ1C220131220", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " RSA, an influential computer security firm, to use a flawed technique that the NSA knew how to crack. The Durov brothers wondered if the same thing could now be happening with other popular encryption algorithms. They became even more concerned when Telegram began to draw public attacks on social media from American cryptography experts. \u201cThey based their criticism of our approach not on any actual weakness, but solely on the fact that we didn\u2019t use the algorithms they were promoting,\u201d he said. \u201cSince they failed to engage in any meaningful conversation on cryptography, we started to realize there was some other agenda they were pushing rather than finding truth or maximizing security.\u201d"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "But the attacks continued. Not only were Snowden and his crypto allies telling people to trust Facebook, a company that runs on surveillance and partners with the NSA; they were also promoting an app that was actively funded by the foreign policy wing of the U.S. national security state. It just didn\u2019t make any sense."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Durov was dumbfounded. As we sat talking, he told me he could not understand how people could trust a supposedly anti-government weapon that was being funded by the very same U.S. government it was supposed to protect its users from."}}, {"_": "PageBlockBlockquote", "text": {"_": "TextItalic", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "We\u2019ve entered a paranoid game theory nightmare world."}}, "caption": {"_": "TextEmpty"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "I told him that I shared his bewilderment. Throughout all my reporting on this set of crypto radicals funded by a CIA spinoff, I asked a simple question that no one could properly answer: If apps like Signal really posed a threat to the NSA\u2019s surveillance power, why would the U.S. government continue to fund them? I couldn\u2019t help but think of how this alignment of government and corporate power would have been received among the tech and media establishment in the United States had something similar taken place in the former Soviet Union: imagine if the KGB funded a special crypto fax line and told Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and dissident samizdat writers to use it, promising that it was totally shielded from KGB operatives. Then imagine that Solzhenitsyn would not only believe the KGB, but would tell all his dissident buddies to use it: \u201cIt\u2019s totally safe.\u201d The KGB\u2019s efforts would be mercilessly ridiculed in the capitalist West, while Solzhenitsyn would be branded a collaborator at worst, or a stooge at best. Ridiculous as this fusion of tech and state interests under the rubric of dissidence is on the face of things, in America this plan can somehow fly."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "As I laid out this analogy, Durov nodded in agreement. \u201cI don\u2019t think it\u2019s a coincidence that we both understand how na\u00efve this kind of thinking is, and that we were both born in the Soviet Union.\u201d"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Trusting the Force"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Political agreement wasn\u2019t exactly what I was expecting when I prepared to meet with Pavel Durov. From what I had read in the press, our politics and view of the world could not be further apart. He was a libertarian, a guy who threw 5,000-ruble notes down at pedestrians just to watch them scramble and fight to pick them up, someone who tweeted out that Hitler and Stalin were no different on the day that people across the former Soviet Union celebrated their victory over Nazi Germany."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Still, on a personal level, he was likeable and even humble. For someone in the crypto world, he was also unexpectedly realistic about the limits of cryptography, displaying none of the cult-like belief in technology that you see in America\u2019s privacy movement. But there was something else as well: he was a fighter."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Begin with the simple fact that he was publicly coming out to detail the FBI\u2019s attempt to bribe his team and pressure Telegram into secretly working with the agency\u2014despite Durov\u2019s own disclaimers and efforts to downplay the revelation, it was a big deal. Despite being chased out of Russia, he wasn\u2019t throwing in with the U.S. security apparatus, but electing instead to fight a two-front war. It was an unusual and impressive move. Most people who run afoul of politics in Russia and find themselves seeking safety in the West as modern-day dissidents usually fall into line with the West\u2019s own propaganda aims, uncritically siding with American interests and players, no matter how unpleasant. Think Pussy Riot fleeing Russia and criticizing Vladimir Putin, while doing photo ops with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "As far as his cryptography, well, there\u2019s no assurance that Telegram will prove to be more secure than its Silicon Valley rivals. Then again, there\u2019s no way that the West\u2019s spy-funded, profit-driven quest for online privacy can yield any reasonable approximation of the real thing, either."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "In our post-Snowden world, we have outsourced our privacy politics to crypto apps. By doing so, we\u2019ve entered a paranoid game theory nightmare world\u2014a place where regular people have no true power and must put their faith in the people and organizations stoking the algorithms that make this crypto tech. In the end, it all comes down to trust. But can any of these people and organizations be really trusted? The young Russian mogul on the skids with the Kremlin? The former American spy-for-hire on the run and hiding out in Russia? Boutique crypto apps funded by the regime change wing of the State Department? Google and Facebook, who partner with the NSA?"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Confused? Don\u2019t know who to trust? Well, that\u2019s the state of our privacy movement today."}}], "photos": [], "documents": [], "part": false, "rtl": false, "v2": false, "views": null}, "attributes": []}}, "reply_markup": null, "entities": [{"_": "MessageEntityUrl", "offset": 117, "length": 55, "entity_text": "https://thebaffler.com/salvos/the-crypto-keepers-levine"}], "views": 485281, "forwards": 1647, "replies": null, "edit_date": "2021-12-30 16:43:57.000000", "post_author": null, "grouped_id": null, "reactions": {"_": "MessageReactions", "results": [{"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc4d"}, "count": 207, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\u2764"}, "count": 65, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83c\udf89"}, "count": 44, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc4e"}, "count": 13, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83e\udd21"}, "count": 12, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83e\udee1"}, "count": 10, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc4f"}, "count": 7, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83c\udfc6"}, "count": 7, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc33"}, "count": 6, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udd25"}, "count": 3, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83e\udd84"}, "count": 3, "chosen_order": null}], "min": false, "can_see_list": false, "recent_reactions": []}, "restriction_reason": [], "ttl_period": null}
{"_": "Message", "id": 58, "peer_id": {"_": "PeerChannel", "channel_id": 1006503122}, "date": "2017-08-27 15:01:03.000000", "message": "New Rules for Alternative Telegram Clients\n\nAmong many other things, Telegram is unique in that independent developers can create their own Telegram clients. The source code of all our apps is open, and we provide a 100% open and free API on the server side for anyone to build upon. \n\nThis level of openness and transparency is unprecedented for mass market messaging apps, and we are proud to provide it. Thanks to this, hundreds of third-party client apps were created for Telegram, and some of them have now reached tens of millions of downloads. \n\nAs the Telegram ecosystem grows, however, a need for consistency and predictability arises. This is particularly important when the privacy of users is concerned. For example, self-destructing media should always get self-destructed in all apps in the ecosystem. Providing a way to keep self-destructing media on the receiving end may be tempting, but this would break the trust and violate the privacy of the users that share them.\n\nThis is why earlier this week we updated the Terms of Service of the Telegram API. Not much has changed: our API is as free and open, as always. However, we\u2019ve added some new guidelines to the ToS, which are aimed at better protecting the privacy and security of the users, preserving expected behavior across the ecosystem, and also at increasing the transparency of how third-party forks work. \n\nIf you are a user or a developer of an alternative Telegram client, please have a look at the updated Terms of Service here \u2013 https://core.telegram.org/api/terms. We hope that these new guidelines will allow third party developers to make their apps more useful and secure than ever.", "out": false, "mentioned": false, "media_unread": false, "silent": true, "post": true, "from_scheduled": false, "legacy": false, "edit_hide": false, "pinned": false, "noforwards": false, "from_id": null, "fwd_from": null, "via_bot_id": null, "reply_to": null, "media": {"_": "MessageMediaWebPage", "webpage": {"_": "WebPage", "id": 2478687561021078614, "url": "https://core.telegram.org/api/terms", "display_url": "core.telegram.org/api/terms", "hash": 2040153095, "type": "article", "site_name": "core.telegram.org", "title": "Telegram API Terms of Service", "description": "We welcome all developers to use our API and source code to create Telegram-like messaging applications on our platform\u2026", "photo": null, "embed_url": null, "embed_type": null, "embed_width": null, "embed_height": null, "duration": null, "author": "Telegram", "document": null, "cached_page": {"_": "Page", "url": "https://core.telegram.org/api/terms", "blocks": [{"_": "PageBlockTitle", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Telegram API Terms of Service"}}, {"_": "PageBlockAuthorDate", "author": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Telegram"}, "published_date": "1970-01-01 00:00:00.000000"}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "We welcome all developers to use our API and source code to "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "create Telegram-like messaging applications"}, "url": "https://core.telegram.org/api/obtaining_api_id", "webpage_id": 2478687560479232813}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " on our platform free of charge. Privacy & Security"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "1.1."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " Telegram is a privacy-oriented platform. All client apps must, therefore, guard their users' privacy with utmost care and comply with our "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Security Guidelines"}, "url": "https://core.telegram.org/mtproto/security_guidelines", "webpage_id": 2478687561036118898}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": ".\n"}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "1.2."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " Developers are welcome to add new features or improve and extend existing Telegram features provided that these modifications do not violate these Terms of Service.\n"}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "1.3."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " As a client developer, you must make sure that all the basic features of the main Telegram apps function correctly and in an expected way both in your app and when users of your app communicate with other Telegram users. It is forbidden to force users of other Telegram clients to download your app in order to view certain messages and content sent using your app.\n"}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "1.4."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " It is forbidden to interfere with the basic functionality of Telegram. This includes but is not limited to: making actions on behalf of the user without the user's knowledge and consent, preventing self-destructing content from disappearing, preventing last seen and online statuses from being displayed correctly, tampering with the 'read' statuses of messages (e.g. implementing a 'ghost mode'), preventing typing statuses from being sent/displayed, etc."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "2-transparency"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2. Transparency"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2.1."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " You must "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "obtain your own api_id"}, "url": "https://core.telegram.org/api/obtaining_api_id#obtaining-api-id", "webpage_id": 2478687560479232813}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " for your application.\n"}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2.2."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " We offer our API free of charge, but your users must be aware of the fact that your app uses the Telegram API and is part of the Telegram ecosystem. This fact must be featured prominently in the app's description in the app stores and in the in-app intro if your app has it.\n"}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2.3."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " To avoid confusion, the title of your app must not include the word \u201cTelegram\u201d. An exception can be made if the word \u201cTelegram\u201d is preceded with the word \u201cUnofficial\u201d in the title.\n"}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2.4."}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " You must not use the official Telegram logo for your app. Both the Telegram brand and its logo are registered trademarks protected by law in almost every country."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "3-advertising-amp-monetization"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "3. {"_": "Message", "id": 57, "peer_id": {"_": "PeerChannel", "channel_id": 1006503122}, "date": "2017-08-14 16:20:50.000000", "message": "Speaking of Telegram's superior technology, a user recently asked me why Telegram \u201cisn\u2019t end-to-end encrypted by default\u201d while some other popular apps are. The question is based on a popular myth, so I wrote a lengthy post about Telegram architecture to disprove it: http://telegra.ph/Why-Isnt-Telegram-End-to-End-Encrypted-by-Default-08-14\n\nIn short: when it comes to popular / usable messaging apps, Telegram is the most secure way of communication \u2013 was, is, and will be.", "out": false, "mentioned": false, "media_unread": false, "silent": true, "post": true, "from_scheduled": false, "legacy": false, "edit_hide": false, "pinned": false, "noforwards": false, "from_id": null, "fwd_from": null, "via_bot_id": null, "reply_to": null, "media": {"_": "MessageMediaWebPage", "webpage": {"_": "WebPage", "id": 5081221152463710690, "url": "https://telegra.ph/Why-Isnt-Telegram-End-to-End-Encrypted-by-Default-08-14", "display_url": "telegra.ph/Why-Isnt-Telegram-End-to-End-Encrypted-by-Default-08-14", "hash": 1819660324, "type": "article", "site_name": "Telegraph \u2013 Pavel Durov", "title": "Why Isn\u2019t Telegram End-to-End Encrypted by Default?\u00a0", "description": "I've been getting this question more often this year.\u00a0It's based on the wrong assumption that some other popular messaging apps such as WhatsApp are \"end-to-end encrypted by default\", while Telegram is not. This post is intended to disprove this myth that has been so carefully crafted by Facebook/WhatsApp marketing efforts. Let\u2019s start from the basics. How Popular Messaging Apps Handle Backups Every popular messaging app offers its users some way to back up their messages to prevent data loss. Messaging apps\u2026", "photo": null, "embed_url": null, "embed_type": null, "embed_width": null, "embed_height": null, "duration": null, "author": "Pavel Durov", "document": null, "cached_page": {"_": "Page", "url": "https://telegra.ph/Why-Isnt-Telegram-End-to-End-Encrypted-by-Default-08-14", "blocks": [{"_": "PageBlockChannel", "channel": {"_": "Channel", "id": 1006503122, "title": "Du Rove's Channel", "photo": {"_": "ChatPhoto", "photo_id": 155759888548607294, "dc_id": 1, "has_video": false, "stripped_thumb": "AQgIpxbS5G7cxPFFFFCEzw=="}, "date": "2015-10-28 18:20:58.000000", "creator": false, "left": false, "broadcast": true, "verified": true, "megagroup": false, "restricted": false, "signatures": false, "min": true, "scam": false, "has_link": false, "has_geo": false, "slowmode_enabled": false, "call_active": false, "call_not_empty": false, "fake": false, "gigagroup": false, "noforwards": false, "join_to_send": false, "join_request": false, "forum": false, "access_hash": -3781798829404003073, "username": "durov", "restriction_reason": [], "admin_rights": null, "banned_rights": null, "default_banned_rights": null, "participants_count": null, "usernames": []}}, {"_": "PageBlockTitle", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Why Isn\u2019t Telegram End-to-End Encrypted by Default?\u00a0"}}, {"_": "PageBlockAuthorDate", "author": {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Pavel Durov"}, "url": "https://t.me/durov", "webpage_id": 0}, "published_date": "2017-08-14 14:24:38.000000"}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "I've been getting this question more often this year.\u00a0It's based on the wrong assumption that some other popular messaging apps such as WhatsApp are \"end-to-end encrypted by default\", while Telegram is not. This post is intended to disprove this myth that has been so carefully crafted by Facebook/WhatsApp marketing efforts. Let\u2019s start from the basics."}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "How-Popular-Messaging-Apps-Handle-Backups"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "How Popular Messaging Apps Handle Backups"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Every popular messaging app offers its users some way to back up their messages to prevent data loss. Messaging apps that ignore backups (such as Wickr/Signal/Confide) never reach mass audience and remain niche. I\u2019ll describe their approach in detail later in this post."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "As for popular apps such as WhatsApp, Viber and Line, they rely on Apple iCloud and Google Drive to store their users' message history and prevent data loss in case their users lose their smartphones. These backups are not e2e-encrypted and get decrypted whenever the user buys a new phone and restores their WhatsApp/Viber/Line message history. While it may seem that you, as a user, have the freedom to opt out of these backups, in reality there\u2019s little room for choice: even if you opt out (which is unusual and sometimes tricky), people you chat with most likely won\u2019t. "}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "This creates a situation when messages you send and receive end up not e2e-encrypted in the cloud without you even realizing it. You have zero transparency on what is really e2e-encrypted and what is backed up. You rely on e2e encryption and trust the \u201cno third party can access my messages\u201d mantra, but your private data is in fact vulnerable to hackers and governments that can get access to it via the cloud storage. If you think this is a minor threat, think again: according to stats WhatsApp shared during Google IO last year, most of the \u201ce2e-encrypted\u201d chats on WhatsApp eventually get backed up and stored in the cloud, not e2e-encrypted."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "WhatsApp's approach has other architectural drawbacks that "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "invalidate end-to-end encryption for 99% of private conversations"}, "url": "https://telegra.ph/whatsapp-backdoor-01-16", "webpage_id": 5081221152245971778}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": ", but in this post I\u2019ll focus mainly on backups for simplicity. "}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "How-Niche-Messaging-Apps-Handle-Backups"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "How Niche Messaging Apps Handle Backups"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The Signal/Wickr/Confide approach is more secure as chats never get backed up. This looks neat, but two problems arise when you restrict your users this way:"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "1) Users don\u2019t want to lose their entire message history when they lose/change their phones so apps of this kind never become massively popular. Obviously, there are also other reasons at play why niche apps remain niche, but an average user is unlikely to download a separate app if the same functionality already exists in a mainstream app she's using (such as Secret Chats in Telegram or their copycat versions in Viber or Facebook Messenger, which also provide e2ee and don\u2019t get backed up).\u00a0"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2) Consequence of (1) \u2013 people using these apps can be targeted by governments as those who have something to hide. Due to the limited distribution of such apps, the government can identify and track individuals whose phones connect to the corresponding IP addresses. This is something that is already happening in case of tools like Tor, and, to a lesser extent, of some messaging apps. Yasha Levine is publishing a "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "brilliant investigation"}, "url": "https://surveillancevalley.com/blog/government-backed-privacy-tools-are-not-going-to-protect-us-from-president-trump", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " about it."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "The-Telegram-Way"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "The Telegram Way"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Back in 2013, when we were launching Telegram, we carefully considered both approaches. We knew we didn\u2019t want to violate our users\u2019 privacy by shifting the responsibility for their data to third-party backups like WhatsApp or Viber do. Neither did we want to deprive our users of functionality that they enjoyed in other apps and doom Telegram to join the ranks of niche apps. \u00a0"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "So after some research we decided to introduce 2 kinds of chats \u2013 Secret chats and Cloud chats.\u00a0"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Secret chats are e2e-encrypted chats that never under any circumstances get backed up. Cloud chats are encrypted in the same way, but also have a built-in cloud backup. Cloud chats are designed for the majority of users \u2013 the majority that in another app like WhatsApp would rely on less secure third-party backup storage. Unlike what you have in niche apps, the traffic between cloud chat users and secret chat users on Telegram is mixed (the encryption is the same in both cases, but in cloud chats our servers do have access to the encryption key), so individuals can not be singled out and targeted based on the fact that they use secret chats and thus have something to hide.\u00a0"}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "4-Reasons-Why-The-Telegram-Way-Makes-More-Sense"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "4 Reasons Why The Telegram Way Makes More Sense"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "There are "}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "four"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " main reasons why we decided to use two types of chats as opposed to having one type of chats like older apps such as WhatsApp:"}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "1) Unlike WhatsApp, we don\u2019t give out our users\u2019 data to third parties via backups. Instead, we rely on our own "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "distributed cross-jurisdictional encrypted cloud storage"}, "url": "https://telegram.org/faq#q-do-you-process-data-requests", "webpage_id": 4108701751824606972}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " which we believe is much more protected than what megacorporations like Google and Apple can offer. To give you an idea about this difference: while Telegram has disclosed no private data to third-parties from its cloud so far, this year alone Apple satisfied "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "80% of data requests from the Chinese (!) government"}, "url": "https://images.apple.com/legal/privacy/transparency/requests-2016-H2-en.pdf", "webpage_id": 0}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " (and "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "is even building a data-center for private iCloud data"}, "url": "https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/13/15964220/apple-china-data-center-icloud-new-cybersecurity-law-guizhou", "webpage_id": 1337119304692506626}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " in China). "}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "2) Unlike WhatsApp, we can allow our users to access their Telegram message history from several devices "}, {"_": "TextBold", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "at once"}}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " thanks to our built-in instant cloud sync. Thus we can provide easy and consistent UX on macs, PCs, iPads and even linux servers."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "3) Unlike on WhatsApp, on Telegram you don\u2019t have to store your entire message history on your phone all the time \u2013 you can always download older messages and media on demand when you need them. This saves a lot of disk space and memory, which is particularly important for our users in the developing markets. On Telegram, shortage of local storage never leads to data loss."}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "4) Unlike WhatsApp, Telegram is able to provide its users with advanced functionality, such as "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "persistent group chats with up to 10,000 members"}, "url": "https://telegram.org/blog/admin-revolution", "webpage_id": 4108701750315064788}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " or channels with "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "no limit on max size"}, "url": "https://telegram.org/blog/channels-2-0", "webpage_id": 4108701750890071592}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": ". These technologies can not be implemented within the \u201ce2ee+third-party backups\u201d paradigm. Our roadmap is filled with features that are impossible to build on a obsolete architecture like WhatsApp's that has to rely on third-party backups instead of relying on its own built-in cloud accessible in real-time."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "These are the reasons why we, ultimately, decided to go with the \u201ctwo kinds of chats\u201d approach, which is more secure (Telegram cloud is better protected than Apple/Google storage), more transparent (you can actually see which of your e2e-encrypted messages go to the cloud and which don\u2019t) and more feature-rich (we can implement features that I mentioned above and many more in the future). We believe our \u201ctwo kinds of chats\u201d approach makes more sense in the long run, which is why it has since been copied by Kakao (2014), Line (2015), and last year by Google Allo and Facebook Messenger. These companies did their own research that proved that the Telegram way is more scalable, secure and transparent."}}, {"_": "PageBlockAnchor", "name": "So-Why-Do-People-Ask-This-Question?"}, {"_": "PageBlockHeader", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "So Why Do People Ask This Question?"}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextConcat", "texts": [{"_": "TextPlain", "text": "I think the myth about Telegram being less secure than WhatsApp originated in a misleading 2016 article by Gizmodo (\u201cWhy you should never use Telegram\u201d) which claimed a lot of things that are not true. A member of our team wrote "}, {"_": "TextUrl", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "an extensive review of that article"}, "url": "https://telegra.ph/Why-you-should-stop-reading-Gizmodo-right-now-Long", "webpage_id": 5081221150718922959}, {"_": "TextPlain", "text": " exposing some of the misconceptions that I\u2019ve also described in this post."}]}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "Every year Facebook \u2013 the company that owns WhatsApp \u2013 spends millions of dollars on marketing, influencing journalists and bloggers. By contrast, Telegram has spent zero dollars on marketing since we started in 2013. Nevertheless, every day at least half a million new users sign up for Telegram, and Telegram's organic annual growth rate exceeds 50%. We owe this growth only to you \u2013 our users and the Telegram community. "}}, {"_": "PageBlockParagraph", "text": {"_": "TextPlain", "text": "I hope this post gives an idea about how Telegram works and why we believe our architecture makes more sense than that of the older apps. "}}], "photos": [], "documents": [], "part": false, "rtl": false, "v2": false, "views": null}, "attributes": []}}, "reply_markup": null, "entities": [{"_": "MessageEntityUrl", "offset": 268, "length": 73, "entity_text": "http://telegra.ph/Why-Isnt-Telegram-End-to-End-Encrypted-by-Default-08-14"}], "views": 370104, "forwards": 431, "replies": null, "edit_date": "2021-12-30 13:51:20.000000", "post_author": null, "grouped_id": null, "reactions": {"_": "MessageReactions", "results": [{"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc4d"}, "count": 218, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\u2764"}, "count": 59, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83c\udf89"}, "count": 30, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc4e"}, "count": 13, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83e\udd21"}, "count": 13, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udd25"}, "count": 10, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83c\udfc6"}, "count": 7, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc4f"}, "count": 6, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83e\udee1"}, "count": 6, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc85"}, "count": 6, "chosen_order": null}, {"_": "ReactionCount", "reaction": {"_": "ReactionEmoji", "emoticon": "\ud83d\udc33"}, "count": 2, "chosen_order": null}], "min": false, "can_see_list": false, "recent_reactions": []}, "restriction_reason": [], "ttl_period": null}
{"_": "Message", "id": 56, "peer_id": {"_": "PeerChannel", "channel_id": 1006503122}, "date": "2017-08-14 16:19:32.000000", "message": "We launched Telegram for iOS exactly 4 years ago, on the 14th of August, 2013. It\u2019s been an amazing 4 years, mostly because of your continuous support and feedback.\n\nTelegram is growing like a rocket: 50+% annual growth rate in MAU/DAU, over half a million daily signups. And while you can do a lot with Telegram already, there are many more features and ideas that we are yet to implement. It might sound like a cliche, but this is just the beginning.\n\nI know you love Telegram for its superior technology and constant innovation. But I believe the real value of Telegram lies in you \u2013 the dedicated Telegram community that shares our passion for freedom and privacy (don\u2019t worry though, the tech superiority part is not {"_": "Message", "id": 55, "peer_id": {"_": "PeerChannel", "channel_id": 1006503122}, "date": "2017-08-10 15:35:29.000000", "message": "What is Instant View and Why It's Important\n\nA few years ago, Telegram was one of the first messaging apps to generate previews for links shared in messages. Since then, some of our competitors started to do the same, but we at Telegram like to raise the bar when it comes to messaging. Our ambition now is not only to show you a small snippet previewing the link you were sent, but to give you a quick and easy way to view the contents of the link without having to load the page in your browser.\n\nWe call this technology instant View. Instant View is a way to read articles without leaving Telegram, just like you can read this post from the Telegram blog https://telegram.org/blog/first-IV-contest (don\u2019t click on the link, tap Instant View below this message on iOS/Android). Instant View is also the most private and secure means of viewing web stories, because your IP address, cookies and metadata are not logged this way.\n\nThe big news this week is that Instant View now supports links from 2,277 websites. From now on, not just Telegram or Medium blog posts, but links to stories of pretty much every mainstream media have an Instant View. This is the result of an epic crowdsourcing effort of 558 coders, who have submitted 37,507 sets of rules to generate instant views. Since May, our platform allowed alternative sets of rules to compete, so that the most accurate ones would ultimately win and bring $100 each to their authors. \n\nAs a result, we distributed $251,664 as prizes among 206 winners. This might seem like a lot of money, but no one has ever done anything like that before \u2013 the winners virtually helped us parse a big chunk of the internet into a predictable format. The scope of this project is unprecedented, and I\u2019m certain we\u2019re a few years ahead of the competition here (to be fair \u2013 Facebook has a similar tech called Instant Articles, but it supports only a handful of web-sites, because, unlike Instant Views, it requires significant effort from publishers to set it up).\n\nOn some Instant Views you will see a \u2018Join\u2019 button that allows you to subscribe to the channel of the media that published the story. This means their news site added a code on its page that refers to its Telegram channel (like <meta name=\"telegram:channel\" content=\u201c@nameofthechannel\u201d>). This will allow publishers to establish direct connection with their readers on Telegram, eventually monetizing this link sharing activity on our platform. \n\nOf course, there\u2019s still a lot left to do. If Instant View is gradually replacing your web-browser for links, its UI should have features that will allow you to bookmark a page to return to it later (bookmarks, tabs, history). And while 2,277 is already a huge and unprecedented number (the full list of supported domains is here https://instantview.telegram.org/contest), eventually we\u2019d like to support many more websites. The end goal is to make almost all the stories that you share on Telegram instantly viewable.", "out": false, "mentioned": false, "media_unread": false, "silent": true, "post": true, "from_scheduled":
